newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian dollar closes flat in quiet trading.
newsitem.headline: Canadian dollar closes flat in quiet trading.

text.p: FORECAST RANGE 1.3690/1.3745 ASIAN CLOSE 1.3715
RESISTANCE 1.3640 SUPPORT 1.3800 HI 1.3727 LO 1.3705
CANADA OPEN 1.3715/20 HI 1.3724 EUROPE OPEN 1.3710
* Canada dollar closes slightly softer at C$1.3718 (US$0.7290) from Wednesday's finish of C$1.3711 (US$0.7294) in quiet trading.
* Market players awaiting Canadian consumer price index numbers to be released Friday, traders said.
* A Royal Bank report forecasts a stronger Canada.
"Beginning in 1997, Canada is set to grow faster on a real basis than any other G7 country," the report said. "At the same time, we expect the Canadian dollar to rise."
Canada has worked to keep inflation down while making dramatic improvements in the current account since 1990.
Low inflation and the recent current account surplus will also add up to a stronger Canadian currency, the bank said.

The report predicts real interest rates will continue to fall in Canada as markets acknowledge the change in Canada's economy. Lower real rates are "key to Canada's approaching economic outperformance," the report said.
Real rates have already fallen by 200 basis points in the last 20 months. The bank forecasts a continued fall by as much as 150 basis points.
Such a fall would put real rates in Canada after inflation about 100 basis points above U.S. rates.
"With such a signficant decline in real rates in Canada, private investment will likely rise sharply," the report said.
Rising private investment will create conditions for sustainable growth in full-time employment in 1998 and 1999 and lead to a rise in personal consumption, said the report.
There is little risk of inflation, it predicted.
Slack in Canada's labor market means a low risk of inflation until the turn of the century, the paper stated.

"Thus, the Canadian economy is likely to grow for three years at almost twice the potential growth rate of the G7 (2.2 percent) without inflation and without a significant increase in interest rates," it said.
Canada will also attract more foreign investment as U.S. companies rush to invest in the improving Canadian environment, the report said.
On the crosses, the Canada rose to 1.1024 marks from 1.1015 marks, but slid to 80.27 yen from 80.47 yen.
-- Reuters Toronto Bureau 416 941-8100
